Graphical abstract In this paper, we report a very simple preparation method for Mg–Al hydrotalcites (HTs) as base catalysts via the hydration of their corresponding metal oxides (MgO and Al2O3) without any particular controlled variables. We also propose a reasonable explanation for a series of reaction pathways in which Mg–Al HTs are formed from their metal oxides. The Mg–Al HTs were formed by the reaction of Mg2+ and Al(OH)4 −, which resulted from the hydration of both metal oxides. The prepared Mg–Al HTs retained their unique properties, including their layered hydroxide structure and memory effect and showed considerable catalytic activity in the isomerization of glucose to fructose. Consequently, this simple hydration of both metal oxides successfully synthesized Mg–Al HTs, which can be used as base catalysts or as catalyst precursors for calcined HTs in various base-catalyzed reactions. Keywords Hydrotalcite Preparation method Metal oxide Hydration Base catalyst 1 Introduction Hydrotalcites (HTs) are well-known layered double hydroxides (LDH) that have the general formula [M2+ 1-xM3+ x(OH)2][An− x/n·mH2O], where M2+ and M3+ represents metal components with divalent and trivalent cations, respectively. For the divalent metal component, magnesium is the most common, although many other metal species with a cation size similar to that of Mg are also available, such as Co, Cu, Ni, Ca, Zn, and Mn. Al generally occupies the positions of the trivalent metal component, although Fe and Cr can be also employed [1–5]. The isomorphous substitution of M2+ by M3+ leads to a brucite-like (Mg(OH)2) layered structure and excessive positive charges. Accordingly, some available anions, such as CO3 2−, NO3 −, Cl−, SO4 2−, and OH− are located in the interlayer along with water molecules to compensate for the excessive positive charges. As a result, HTs have a unique layered structure with positively charged brucite-like layers and compensating anions [6–10]. Due to their unique structures, HTs have two representative and prominent properties: the ability to capture and exchange organic and inorganic anions and memory effect. These unique properties have resulted in these compounds having a wide range of applications as anion exchangers, absorbing agents, stabilizers for polymers, catalysts, electroactive materials, and pharmaceuticals [11–13]. As such, many attempts have been made to synthesize HTs with unique properties to meet the specific requirements of various application areas. Accordingly, various preparation techniques have been extensively investigated, including the co-precipitation method, sol-gel method, hydrothermal synthesis, microwave irradiation, and electrochemical methods. The preparation techniques of HTs were well reviewed by M.R. Othman et al. [14]. Although the co-precipitation method has been widely employed in previous studies, in the preparation of HTs it has a severe drawback in the excessive number of parameters that must be considered during the co-precipitation step, which affects the successful formation of HTs. These parameters include pH value, temperature, metal precursor, and aging time. Moreover, keeping the pH value of solution constant throughout the entire precipitation procedure is very difficult even when high-speed stirring is employed, which leads to the low crystallinity of HT. Moreover, the urea method, which uses urea as a precipitating and pH-control agent, is very sensitive to temperature during preparation. As such, temperature control is a key factor in obtaining HT by the urea method. In addition to the above two typical preparation methods, sol-gel, hydrothermal, combustion, and steam activation methods can be applied in the preparation of HTs. However, most preparation methods have rather complex preparation processes with inherent problems, such as too many synthetic parameters to achieve precise control, low reproducibility, high preparation cost, and difficulty in mass production [14]. To overcome these problems, here we report a simple method for the preparation of Mg–Al HTs, which are the most representative HTs, using their corresponding metal oxides. Of course, there have been a number of previous attempts to prepare Mg–Al HTs via the hydration of metal oxides [15–18]. G.Q. Lu et al. demonstrated that Mg–Al HTs could be prepared in three steps: dissociation, deposition, and diffusion. Although interesting results regarding the preparation of Mg–Al HTs from their corresponding metal oxides were already reported, there has been a lack of clear discussion about the reaction pathway, or, in particular, its uncommon deposition and diffusion [15]. Furthermore, a slight change in the initial pH value of the precursor solution greatly affects the final product, leading to difficulty in obtaining single-phase Mg–Al HTs. Therefore, the main aim of this paper is to present a very simple preparation method for obtaining single-phase Mg–Al HTs using their metal oxides without any particular controlled variables, and to provide a reasonable explanation for a series of reaction pathways in which Mg–Al HTs are formed from their metal oxides. We hope this paper will contribute to making the preparation process of HTs easy and simple to achieve using commercially available materials. Researchers in the field of heterogeneous catalysts have exhibited great interest in the utilization of the memory effect of HTs for various base-catalyzed reactions, which is a property unique to HTs. In the memory effect of HTs, as-synthesized HTs can be transformed into their corresponding mixed metal oxides by thermal treatment in air, and in turn, the original structure of HTs with layered double hydroxides can be successfully recovered by immersing the mixed metal oxides in water, which is known as the reconstruction process. Our group has consistently studied the tuning of the basic catalytic properties of Mg–Al HTs using this memory effect [19,20]. Accordingly, in addition to preparing Mg–Al HTs using a simple method, in this study we also focused on their memory effect and base catalytic properties. We employed glucose isomerization as a model reaction to explore the catalytic base properties of Mg–Al HTs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation All chemicals were used without further purification. We used two different types of metal oxides as sources of magnesium and aluminum. We purchased commercial metal oxides (MC: MgO commercially provided, AC: Al2O3 commercially provided) from Sigma-Aldrich, and we prepared as-synthesized metal oxides (MS: MgO synthesized in the laboratory, AS: Al2O3 synthesized in the laboratory) by calcining corresponding metal nitrates at 450°C for 10h in air. In a typical procedure, we simultaneously added known amounts of magnesium oxide (1.6g) and aluminum oxide (0.68g) to 100ml of distilled water in a wide-mouth bottle. Then, we sealed the bottle with its cap, and aged the resulting solution containing the magnesium and aluminum sources while vigorously stirring at different temperatures (60 and 80°C) and for different periods of times (6h, 12h, 1 d, 3 d, 5 d, and 7 d). Thereafter, we collected the white precipitate through filtration, and dried it overnight at 80°C in an oven. We denoted the prepared samples as XY_Z, where XY and Z represent the sources of the metal oxides and the aging time, respectively. For example, MSAC_5 d indicates a sample prepared via hydration for 5 d using MgO that was synthesized in the laboratory (MS) and commercially provided Al2O3 (AC). For comparison, we also prepared a Mg–Al hydrotalcite (HT_C) with a ratio of Mg/Al=3 by a co-precipitation method using the procedure reported in our previous work [19]. 2.2 Reconstruction process To confirm the memory effect of the prepared sample, we also conducted a reconstruction process according to the method reported in our previous work [19]. The prepared sample was calcined at 450°C for 10h in air to obtain the calcined Mg–Al HT. Next, we added the calcined Mg–Al HT (approximately 2g) to 100ml of distilled water, and then stirred the resulting solution vigorously in an inert atmosphere at 60°C for 24h. We then filtered the solution to obtain a solid product, and lastly, dried it overnight at 80°C to yield the reconstructed Mg–Al HT. 2.3 Characterization We characterized the crystalline structure of the prepared samples by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement, and recorded the XRD spectra on an X’pert-Pro PANanalytical diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å). We recorded diffraction patterns within a 2θ range of 5–80°. We analyzed the morphological features of the sample by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and obtained SEM images on a JSM-6700F field emission (FE) microscope operating at 15kV. We immobilized the samples on a copper holder using conducting resin and coated them with platinum prior to characterization. We also conducted ICP-AES analysis (PerkinElmer, OPTIMA 4300DV) in order to confirm the metal contents of the samples. The specific surface areas of the samples were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using N2 adsorption and desorption measurements conducted at −196°C with a constant-volume adsorption apparatus (BEL Japan, BELSORP-mini II). In order to confirm the chemical bonds in the samples, infrared spectra were also recorded on a Jasco FT-IR-460 spectrometer in range of 4500–900cm−1 using the KBr pellet technique. Using a mass spectrometer (MS), we carried out thermogravimetric (TG) analysis (NETZSCH, TG209F1) to confirm the thermal behavior of the samples. The TG analyses were carried out in a temperature range of 25–900°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min in an air stream, and recorded MS traces of m/z =18 and 44 for the evolved water and CO2, respectively. 2.4 Procedure for glucose isomerization and product analysis We conducted the isomerization of glucose to fructose in a batch-type glass reactor. In a typical reaction, we used 0.3g of glucose, 0.1g of catalyst, and 10ml of dimethylformamide. The reaction was performed at 100°C for 5h. After the reaction was complete, we cooled the reactor in an ice bath. We then filtered off the catalysts using a syringe filter and analyzed the filtrate by high performance liquid chromatography (Young Lin instrument, YL 9100) using an ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) detector and a refractive index (RI) detector. The mobile phase was 0.005M H2SO4 at a flow rate of 0.5mL/min and we separated the reaction products using a Biorad Aminex HPX87H column at 50°C. We plotted the calibration curves using a series of standard solutions to quantify the glucose and fructose. We determined the glucose conversion and fructose selectivity using the following equations, and calculated the fructose yield by multiplying the conversion and selectivity. Conversion of glucose ( % ) = moles of glucose reacted moles of glucose supplied × 100 Selectivity for fructose ( % ) = moles of fructose formed moles of glucose reacted × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation of hydrotalcites via hydration of metal oxides First, we attempted to synthesize Mg–Al hydrotalcites (HTs) using both metal oxides such as MS (MgO synthesized in the laboratory) and AS (Al2O3 synthesized in the laboratory), which could be easily obtained by the calcination of corresponding metal nitrate precursors in air. Prior to the synthesis of Mg–Al HTs using both metal oxides, we examined the samples obtained via the hydration of a single metal oxide (MS or AS). As shown in Fig. 1 (a), all the MgO diffraction peaks (JCPDS #87-0653) completely disappeared after the hydration process, wherein MS was immersed in water and was then vigorously stirred at 60°C for 1 d. However, in the XRD patterns of the hydrated sample (MS_1 d), there were evident diffraction peaks for Mg(OH)2 (JCPDS #86-0441), which is a well-known mineral as brucite. Considering that positively charged brucite-like layers of metal hydroxides form the basis of the Mg–Al HT structure, these XRD results suggest the high feasibility of a simple preparation method for Mg–Al HTs from metal oxides. In the case of AS, we found two crystalline phases such as bayerite (β-Al(OH)3, JCPDS #77-0250) and boehmite (AlO(OH), JCPDS #76-1871) in the XRD pattern of the AS_1 d sample (Fig. 1(b)). This indicates that amorphous alumina was converted into boehmite and bayerite during the hydration process in water being vigorously stirred at 60°C for 1 d. These results are in good agreement with previous reports that alumina could be transformed into aluminum hydroxide species via the hydration process and different aluminum hydroxides such as bayerite (β-Al(OH)3), gibbsite (α-Al(OH)3), and boehmite (AlO(OH)) could be formed depending on the hydration conditions [21–24]. Fig. 2 shows XRD patterns of the samples prepared by the hydration of both metal oxides (MS and AS) in water for different times. For the purposes of comparison, the XRD pattern of the HT_C, the Mg–Al HT prepared by a co-precipitation method, is also shown. The XRD peaks for MgO (2θ=42.8 and 62.2°) disappeared with an increase in the hydration reaction time. Interestingly, the characteristic peaks of Mg–Al HT at 2θ=11.4 (003), 23.0 (006), and 34.5° (009) (JCPDS #41-1428) gradually developed with increasing hydration time. In single metal oxide (MS or AS) hydrations (Fig. 1), we obtained the corresponding metal hydroxides after the hydration for 1 d, while we found no noticeable peaks for the metal hydroxides (Mg(OH)2, β-Al(OH)3, and AlO(OH)) in the samples prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides. Instead, it appeared as if the two metal oxides (MgO and Al2O3) directly transformed into Mg–Al HT via the hydration reaction (Fig. 2). In the meantime, the XRD peaks for MgO gradually decreased with increasing hydration time. Upon closer examination of the XRD pattern of the MSAS_1 d obtained via the 1 d-hydration reaction of both metal oxides, we found that the XRD peaks for brucite (Mg(OH)2), bayerite (β-Al(OH)3), and Mg–Al HT occurred at the same time (Fig. 3 ). This suggests that Mg–Al HT could be prepared from both metal oxides passing through corresponding hydroxide forms. We can also infer that aluminum oxide could be incorporated into the hydrotalcite structure by way of bayerite (β-Al(OH)3) rather than boehmite (AlO(OH)). The preference for bayerite can be explained by the pH value of the solution during the hydration process. As mentioned earlier, three types of aluminum hydroxides (boehmite, bayerite, and gibbsite) can be obtained from the hydration of aluminum oxide. Also, the hydration reaction conditions strongly affect the formation of aluminum hydroxide, and the pH value of the solution is a particularly important factor in the aluminum hydroxide formation process [21,23,24]. For such a reasons, we examined the pH values of the solution during the hydration of both metal oxides (MS and AS) to prepare the MSAS_7 d, and the obtained results were presented in Fig. S1. From the variation of pH values, it could be inferred that aluminum oxide first transformed into bayerite, which is easily formed in the high pH value solutions (pH>9) of our experimental conditions, and is subsequently incorporated into the layered structures that form Mg–Al HT. Consequently, the XRD analysis results clearly indicated that Mg–Al HT was successfully prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides (MS and AS) through the formation of their metal hydroxides (brucite and bayerite, respectively). The process for magnesium oxide hydration can be explained by its general aspect and the pH value variation of the solution during the hydration process (Fig. S1). During the hydration process, MgO first reacts with water molecules to form MgOH+ and OH−, and then, these ions transform into Mg(OH)2 on the surface of the MgO [25,26]. The Mg(OH)2 then detaches from the MgO surface and simultaneously dissociates into Mg2+ and OH− in an aqueous solution. With respect to the pH value variation of the solution during the hydration process, the initial pH value of the solution was mild basic (ca. 8.3), and increased with the hydration time. Interestingly, the pH value increased for 5 d, and thereafter maintained a constant value (ca. 10.5). We infer from the XRD results (Fig. 2) and the pH value variation (Fig. S1) that magnesium oxide first changed into Mg(OH)2, and subsequently, the Mg(OH)2 dissociated into Mg2+ and OH−, which led to the increase in the solution’s pH value during the hydration process. This process is also in good agreement with the reported mechanism for magnesium oxide hydration [27–30]. The dissociated Mg2+ was finally incorporated into the layered structure with the aluminum species to form Mg–Al HT. However, the dissociation of Mg(OH)2 seems to be thermodynamically limited at too high a pH value (around 10.5), resulting in the formation of Mg(OH)2 as a minor phase in the samples obtained after 5days of the hydration process. This result also implies that the amount of metal oxides and the time employed in the hydration process might be important factors in obtaining single-phase Mg–Al HTs. Moreover, the increase in the pH value might clearly explain the reaction pathway for the formation of Mg–Al HT via the hydration of both metal oxides. As confirmed by XRD analysis, the aluminum component was incorporated into the Mg–Al HT structure by way of bayerite (β-Al(OH)3) under basic conditions [22]. Interestingly, bayerite retains its amphoteric property, and accordingly, is ionized into Al(OH)4 − in basic solutions [31]. Therefore, we assume that the bayerite obtained by the hydration of aluminum oxide was directly ionized with OH−, which is provided sufficiently from the magnesium oxide hydration process, to finally form Al(OH)4 − during the hydration of both metal oxides. Finally, the Al(OH)4 − might react with Mg2+ by the following equation to form Mg–Al HT under basic conditions: 6 Mg 2 + + 2 Al ( OH ) 4 − + 8 OH − + 2 A − + xH 2 O → Mg 6 Al 2 ( OH ) 16 2 A − · xH 2 O. The formation of Al(OH)4 − during aluminum oxide hydration is also supported by ICP-AES analysis, which we conducted using samples with different hydration reaction times (Table S1). The Mg/Al ratios in the samples decreased with increasing hydration times, and finally reached 3.4 after the 1-week hydration reaction. From the ICP-AES analyses and the XRD and pH value variation results, we can easily infer that the aluminum component existed in the form of Al(OH)4 − from the initial stage of the hydration of both metal oxides, leading to high Mg/Al ratios compared to the amount of metal oxide (Mg/Al=3) employed in the hydration process. With an increasing hydration time, Al(OH)4 − and Mg2+ were incorporated into a hydrotalcite structure, and accordingly, the Mg/Al ratio gradually decreased. However, the final Mg/Al ratio after the 7 d-hydration reaction did not reach the designed value of 3, which we attributed to the formation of Mg(OH)2 as a minor phase. Therefore, both the hydration reaction time and the molar ratio of the metal oxides used in the hydration reaction must be precisely controlled when using this method in order to synthesize single-phase Mg–Al HT. We also noted that a new XRD peak for (006) of Mg–Al HT appeared after the 5 d-hydration reaction (MSAS_5 d), which might be explained by the presence of interlayer anions. It is well known that CO3 2− anions are thermodynamically most favorable as compensating interlayer anions in the Mg–Al HT structure [32,33]. In our experiments, however, OH− could be consistently supplied by the dissociation of Mg(OH)2 at the initial stage of hydration. Accordingly, once positively charged hydroxide layers form, it is assumed that OH− ions in the solution could be quickly adsorbed on the surface of these layers to form an anion layer. These results are in good agreement with previous reports [15]. On the other hand, the increase in the solution’s pH value during the hydration process could result in the enhanced solubility of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, leading to abundant CO3 2− species in the solution [34,35]. We also expect this environment to facilitate the formation of an anion layer of CO3 2−. This means that the distance between the positively charged hydroxide layers could increase compared to that of Mg–Al HT with an anion layer of OH−. Evidence for this situation was provided by the appearance of a shoulder peak for (003) and a lower angle peak for (006) in the samples obtained after 5days of the hydration process (MSAS_5 d and MSAS_7 d). Additionally, the interlayer anions could be completely replaced with CO3 2− by the reconstruction process (Fig. 5). Based on the above experimental findings, here, we propose a reaction pathway for the simple preparation method for Mg–Al HTs via the hydration of both metal oxides (Scheme 1 ). In summary, Mg2+ was formed from the dissociation of Mg(OH)2, which was obtained on the surface of the magnesium oxide via the hydration of the magnesium oxide. Through this process, the magnesium oxide consistently served as a magnesium source, supplying Mg2+ for the Mg–Al HT until the pH value of the solution became high enough (ca. 10.5) to initiate the formation of Mg(OH)2 as a minor phase. In the meantime, β-Al(OH)3, which was formed via aluminum oxide hydration in the basic solution, was changed into Al(OH)4 − by abundant the OH− coming from the dissociation of Mg(OH)2. Finally, the Mg2+ and Al(OH)4 − were incorporated into the Mg–Al HT structure. 3.2 Thermal properties of the prepared hydrotalcite Next, to confirm the successful formation of Mg–Al HT, we examined the thermal properties of the MSAS_ 7 d prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides for 7 d. For comparison, we also examined the Mg–Al HT sample (HT_C) prepared by the co-precipitation method. Wide catalytic applications of calcined Mg–Al HTs have led to many investigations of the thermal decomposition of Mg–Al HTs [2,3]. According to the results reported in literatures [36,37], thermal decomposition processes, such as dehydration, dehydroxylation, and decarbonization, mainly proceed during the thermal treatment of HTs. Many researchers also agree that there are three prominent temperature intervals: room temperature −250°C, 250–750°C, and above 750°C, although opinions differ regarding the exact temperature and mechanism of thermal decomposition. Water molecules mainly evolve in the first temperature region from room temperature to 250°C, due to a reversible loss of the interlayer and surface-adsorbed water molecules. In the second temperature region, significant dehydroxylation and decarbonization occur. In this step, the OH groups that are bonded to metal species are detached, and evolve into the form of water. The removal of OH groups in the brucite-like layers results in a loss of cation charges, which allows carbonate and hydroxide ions to evolve as CO2 and water molecules, respectively, at the same time. Until the second step, the structure of the Mg–Al HTs preserves its layered character while transforming the Mg–Al mixed oxides. The mixed oxides can be reconstructed into their original structure by immersing them in water, which is well-known as the memory effect of hydrotalcite. During heating in the final temperature region above 750°C, Mg–Al HTs finally change into mixed phases of MgO and MgAl2O4, and lose their unique memory effect. We observed the general aspect of Mg–Al HTs during thermal treatment in our TG-analysis (Fig. 4 ). We found a typical weight loss of Mg–Al HTs with temperature elevation. Also, the H2O and CO2 molecules evolved within the appropriate temperature regions. With respect to the water molecules (m/z =18), we attribute the first peak to the surface-adsorbed and interlayer water molecules, while the water molecules formed during the recombination of hydroxyl groups from the brucite-like layer contributed to the second peak. Of course, we partially attribute the second peak to the evolution of the OH− interlayer anions. As expected, we also detected interlayer carbonate ions in the form of CO2 within the temperature region of 300–500°C. Along with the XRD results, therefore, the TG results strongly support the proposal that Mg–Al HT can be successfully prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides. As shown in Fig. 4(a), both the MSAS_7 d and HT_C samples showed similar trends in weight loss with increasing temperature, although there were differences in the amount of weight loss. This might be due to the different crystallinity of the two samples (Fig. 2), resulting in different amounts of interlayer and surface-adsorbed water molecules. This result accords with the fact that the first water molecules evolved a little earlier in the HT_C sample due to its relatively less-developed layered structure (Fig. 4(b)). Moreover, we assume that the difference in the amount of weight loss was partially due to the different interlayer anions of the MSAS_7 d (OH− and CO3 2−) and HT_C (CO3 2−). 3.3 Memory effect of the prepared hydrotalcite As mentioned earlier, memory effect is the most prominent characteristic of HTs, so it is very important to check whether the sample prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides retains its memory effect. To confirm the memory effect of the MSAS_7 d, we conducted a general reconstruction process using a method reported in our previous work [19]. First, we transformed the MSAS_7 d into a calcined sample (MSAS_7 d_C) by thermal treatment in air at 450°C for 10h. Next, we obtained the reconstructed sample (MSAS_7 d_R) by immersing the calcined sample in water and vigorously stirring it under nitrogen atmosphere at 60°C for 24h. As shown in the XRD patterns of these three samples (Fig. 5), the MSAS_7 d prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides retained its unique memory effect, and thus retained the capability of reverting into its original layered structure through successive calcination and reconstruction processes. This provides further key evidence that we successfully synthesized Mg–Al HT in this study, using this simple method involving the hydration of both metal oxides. In the XRD patterns of the calcined sample (MSAS_7 d_C), we found very broad diffraction peaks only for the MgO. This suggest that both MgO and Al2O3 were completely mixed without any phase segregation in the MSAS_7 d_C, which would make possible the recovery of the original layered structure by the hydration process. Interestingly, the XRD peaks for the (003), (006), and (009) of the Mg–Al HT were slightly shifted to the left, and we found only a single peak for (006) after the reconstruction process. This suggests that the interlayer anions were mainly composed of CO3 2− in the MSAS_7 d_R and more interlayer water molecular were inserted between the layers during the reconstruction process. Ultimately, this led to an increase in the distance between the positive hydroxide layers in the MSAS_7 d_R. We also note that the characteristic XRD peak for Mg(OH)2 in the MSAS_7 d completely disappeared during the reconstruction process. As a result, we could obtain single-phase Mg–Al HT in the MSAS_7 d_R. As mentioned above, both the hydration reaction time and the molar ratio of the metal oxides employed in the hydration reaction should be precisely controlled to avoid the formation of Mg(OH)2 as a minor phase. Alternatively, we also confirmed that single-phase Mg–Al HT can be easily obtained by the reconstruction of the sample prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides. A variation of specific surface areas of the Mg–Al hydrotalcite samples during the calcination and the reconstruction processes was also examined. The BET surface areas of MSAS_7 d, MSAS_7 d_C, and MSAS_7 d_R were found to be 24.6, 65.4, and 37.2m2/g, respectively. This trend is in good agreement with the previous reports [19,20]. Especially, we assume that an increase in the BET surface area between MSAS_7 d and MSAS_7 d_R was attributed to the facile vertical breaking and exfoliation of hydrotalcite layers during the reconstruction process, as reported in our previous work [20]. We also confirmed the layered structures of the samples prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides by FE-SEM analysis (Fig. 6 ). For comparison, we present them with an SEM image of HT_C, which is well-known for its layered structure. These SEM images clearly demonstrate that both the MSAS_7 d and the MSAS_7 d_R retained their unique morphologies with characteristically layered structures. Consequently, all the characterizations performed in this study lead us to conclude that Mg–Al HT can be successfully prepared using this simple method of the hydration of both metal oxides. To double check the successful formation of the Mg–Al HTs prepared in this study, infrared spectroscopy was carried out over the MSAS_7 d, the MSAS_7 d_R, and the HT_C, the obtained spectra were shown in Fig. S2. As expected, all tested samples showed the characteristic IR peaks for Mg–Al HT. The broad IR peaks at around 3500cm−1 indicate the hydroxyl-stretching in brucite-like layers and hydrogen bonding between water and carbonate anion in the interlayer. Also, the infrared adsorption peaks at ca. 1635 and 1380cm−1 correspond to interlayer water molecules (bending mode) and carbonate anions (v3 mode), respectively. These characteristic IR peaks of the samples are consistent with previous literatures [38–40]. Especially, all IR peaks were identically found in the MSAS_7 d_R and the HT_C spectra, indicating the successful formation of single-phase Mg–Al HT in the MSAS_7 d_R. On the other hand, the MSAS_7 d exhibited an unique peak at 3698cm−1, which was attributed to the stretching of the hydroxyl group in brucite layers (Mg(OH)2) [15,41]. This means that the MSAS_7 d retains a little amount of Mg(OH)2 as minor phase, which is in good agreement with the XRD analysis (Fig. 2). Once again, IR analysis support the conclusion that Mg–Al HT can be successfully prepared using the hydration of both metal oxides. 3.4 Catalytic properties of the prepared hydrotalcites as base catalysts We examined the catalytic activity of the samples prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides using the catalytic isomerization of glucose into fructose. Although Mg–Al HTs are well-known to be efficient and base catalysts, many investigations have focused on calcined Mg–Al HTs with respect to various base-catalyzed reactions, such as Knoevenagel condensation and Michael condensation, in consideration of their strong basic properties and high reaction temperatures [42,43]. In this study, therefore, to investigate the catalytic properties of Mg–Al HTs with layered structures, we chose glucose isomerization as a model reaction, which can be performed at low reaction temperatures on heterogeneous catalysts with relatively weak base sites [19,20]. As shown in Fig. 7 , the MSAS_7 d and MSAS_7 d_R exhibited considerable fructose yields, although the maximum fructose yield was obtained by the HT_C prepared using the co-precipitation method. We assumed that the enhanced catalytic activity of HT_C could be attributed to its abundant surface base sites from its less-developed layered structure, which was confirmed by XRD analysis (Fig. 2). It is also interesting that the fructose selectivity over the MSAS_7 d_R were higher than that over the HT_C, indicating that the simple preparation method via the hydration of both metal oxides might be better than the typical co-precipitation method in synthesizing HTs as selective base catalysts. Consequently, the MSAS_7 d and MSAS_7 d_R served as efficient base catalysts in this reaction. In particular, when considering that the fructose yield is limited by the thermodynamic equilibrium in this reaction (ca. 42% at 50°C) [44], the fructose yields obtained by the Mg–Al HTs prepared in this study seem to be significantly high. Therefore, we expect that the Mg–Al HTs prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides may act as efficient base catalysts in various base-catalyzed reactions, especially those requiring the weak base properties of solid catalysts. Furthermore, we expect this simple method to be an efficient and simple way to prepare precursors for calcined HTs, as they exhibit significant potential in various base-catalyzed reactions. For comparison, the catalytic activities of magnesium oxide (MS) and aluminum oxide (AS) were also examined under the same reaction conditions for the prepared Mg–Al HTs. Both materials exhibited very little catalytic performance in this reaction (yield for fructose: 2.5% (MS) and 1.6% (AS)). Once again, these results support that the Mg–Al HTs prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides were highly selective for glucose isomerization reaction. To check the feasibility of recycling the Mg–Al HTs prepared via the hydration of both metal oxides, recycle experiments were conducted using the MSAS_ 7 d_R. In a typical recycle experiment, the reactor was cooled in an ice bath immediately after the catalytic reaction. Then, the solid catalyst was collected by filtration and washed with ethanol and water to remove adsorbed organic impurities. The obtained catalyst was employed in the next run. Finally, the MSAS_ 7 d_R was reused three times in the same way, and the obtained results were summarized in Table 1 . Even after the third run, the MSAS_ 7 d_R exhibited a considerable catalytic activity without significant loss in the fructose yield. This imply that the Mg–Al HTs prepared in this study could serve as efficient base catalysts in the isomerization of glucose to fructose. We also investigated the catalytic stability of MSAS_7 d_R by comparing XRD patterns before and after the catalyst recycling test. For this purpose, the MSAS_7 d_R_used was recovered after the third run in the recycle experiment and the change in structure of the MSAS_7 d_R was examined. As show in Fig. S3, no changes were found in the XRD patterns of the MSAS_7 d_R between before and after the third run reactions. In other words, the MSAS_7 d_R maintained its initial crystalline phase even after the third run reactions. From the above results, we could confirm that the Mg–Al HTs prepared in this study were stable during the catalytic reaction. 3.5 Preparation of hydrotalcites using various metal oxide sources We also used commercial metal oxides that are readily supplied from chemical companies to attempt to synthesize Mg–Al HTs via the hydration of both metal oxides. We assumed that the use of commercial metal oxides would make the synthesis route for HT even easier and simpler. Prior to this attempt, we had investigated the effects of reaction temperature on hydration, with the goal of reducing the hydration time for obtaining Mg–Al HTs. For this reason, we conducted the hydration process at an elevated reaction temperature (60→80°C). As shown in Fig. S4, we obtained Mg–Al HT only after a 3-d hydration time at 80°C, while it took 7 d to obtain Mg–Al HT via hydration at 60°C. This may be due to the enhanced reaction rates at 80°C in the hydration of metal oxides and the formation of Mg–Al HT. Accordingly, to reduce the time needed to prepare Mg–Al HTs via the hydration of metal oxides, in this study, we then employed a hydration temperature of 80°C. We used commercial metal oxides along with synthesized metal oxides as our metal oxide sources in the hydration processes for synthesizing Mg–Al HTs, specifically: commercial magnesium oxide (MC), commercial aluminum oxide (AC), synthesized magnesium oxide (MS), and synthesized aluminum oxide (AS). The obtained results are summarized in Table 2 and Fig. 8 provides the corresponding XRD patterns in detail. Mg–Al HTs were successfully formed as the main phases in all attempts, regardless of the source of the metal oxide, although the times required for obtaining Mg–Al HTs differed slightly. We can confidently infer that the differences in the hydration time may be attributed to the different hydration reaction rates of the metal oxides. In particular, we found the hydration reaction rate of commercial magnesium oxide to be relatively low compared to that of synthesized magnesium oxide, which led to an increased hydration time for the characteristic XRD for MgO to completely disappear, thus extending the formation time of the Mg–Al HTs (MCAC and MCAS samples). We detected Mg(OH)2 as minor phases in most samples. As mentioned earlier, the dissociation of Mg(OH)2 can be thermodynamically limited under basic conditions (pH=ca. 10.5), resulting in the formation of Mg(OH)2 as a minor phase. Once again, this result implies that the amount of metal oxides and time employed in the hydration process might be important factors in obtaining single-phase Mg–Al HTs. As expected, all the samples prepared via hydration using various metal oxide sources retained their unique memory effects and, thus, were capable of reverting to their original layered structures by reconstruction processes. More importantly, we could obtain single-phase Mg–Al HTs after the reconstruction process for all samples prepared via hydration using various metal oxide sources. Consequently, we conclude that this simple preparation method for Mg–Al HTs can be successfully carried out using various metal oxide sources. 4 Conclusions In this study, we prepared Mg–Al hydrotalcites (HTs) via the simple hydration of their corresponding metal oxides (MgO and Al2O3). During the hydration process of magnesium oxide, Mg(OH)2 formed on the surface of the MgO, and subsequently dissociated into Mg2+ and OH−. Meanwhile, β-Al(OH)3 obtained via aluminum oxide hydration in a basic solution and OH− resulted from the dissociation of Mg(OH)2 created Al(OH)4 −. Finally, Mg2+ and Al(OH)4 − were incorporated into the Mg–Al HT structure. The prepared Mg–Al HTs retained their unique properties of a layered structure and memory effect, indicating the successful formation of Mg–Al HTs. Furthermore, Mg–Al HTs prepared by this simple method served as efficient base catalysts in the isomerization of glucose to fructose. This method was also used to successfully synthesize Mg–Al HTs using a variety of metal oxide sources, such as commercial and synthesized oxides. Consequently, the simple hydration of metal oxides can make the synthesis route for Mg-Al HTs easier and simpler, and we expect the prepared Mg–Al HTs to apply to various base-catalyzed reactions. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, we report a very simple preparation method for Mg–Al hydrotalcites (HTs) as base catalysts via the hydration of their corresponding metal oxides (MgO and Al2O3) without any particular controlled variables. We also propose a reasonable explanation for a series of reaction pathways in which Mg–Al HTs are formed from their metal oxides. The Mg–Al HTs were formed by the reaction of Mg2+ and Al(OH)4 −, which resulted from the hydration of both metal oxides. The prepared Mg–Al HTs retained their unique properties, including their layered hydroxide structure and memory effect and showed considerable catalytic activity in the isomerization of glucose to fructose. Consequently, this simple hydration of both metal oxides successfully synthesized Mg–Al HTs, which can be used as base catalysts or as catalyst precursors for calcined HTs in various base-catalyzed reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Simple preparation method for Mg–Al hydrotalcites as base catalysts
